Everything a film should be, but very RARELY is: Entertaining. Just the right sprinkling of humor, inspiring, well-cast, well-acted, well- paced, well-edited - an absolute joy to watch as the story played out to it's conclusion. The wrestling competition scenes by these young girls were the most believable and realistic sports-action scenes I've seen in ANY movie. Sound track was very good. Subtitles were short and not a distraction to viewing the film at all, and oddly seemed to add to the overall impact and success of the film.The few photos of the family who lived this story, as the credits rolled, were a delight. As depicted in this film, there are aspects of the Indian culture and family values that are worth emulating. New Years Day theater was packed. Thank you to AMC for making this limited release gem available at one of your theaters in our area (only one!!?). It deserves a much wider release.

In the movie, Geeta, the eldest daughter, trains with her father and plays for the first time. Four boys lined up, some thin, some sturdy, and Geeta chose. Of course, everyone in the audience believed that even the weakest boy could beat the Geeta girl. But Geeta chose his strongest rival.Like all the wrestling scenes in the show, the fight that followed was real and exciting. Opponents at first disdain, suffered a loss, soon learned to handle with caution. Geeta was focused, trying to seize every opportunity. The audience also from the relaxed mood of watching the play, become nervous and engaged. Geeta lost to his opponent but won the respect of the crowd. But she was disappointed. Her father said she had conquered her fear.Geeta had lived passively under his father's demon training. Even if we agree ideologically with our father, we can't get a glimpse of Geeta's true character. But this simple choice on the field brought Geeta's character to light. As my father later concluded, Geeta was an aggressive tiger. This domineering choice was the best preparation for Geeta's fate. Even if the opponent is bigger, even if Geeta is lost, we also know that this girl's heart sleeps a fierce tiger.Choice is an exam question.Let's think about another girl. She lived in developed Europe and America and loved wrestling since childhood. With the support of her parents, she met the best coach and successfully won the Olympic championship. In such a life, the dream is like the lamp, no longer need to choose the trouble. Just such a film is made out, at most is a youth inspirational fairy tale: sweet but difficult to shock people. This is not to say that there are no plain sailing people. It is only in the face of difficult choices that human nature is often fully manifested. Moviegoers are willing to sit in front of the screen for two or three hours, expecting to see the true humanity of the choices.Because of the choice of time and often, the character of the character becomes three-dimensional. The father is stubborn and conceited, but when he massages his daughter's ankles, he questions his own harshness. Even when he had chosen the road for his daughter, he had added a year's time to his worries. When the professional coach humiliates in front of him, his father, who always refuses to admit defeat, takes it in his face. But when the daughter sobbed on the other end of the phone, the father did not hesitate, the next day to the daughter's city, quietly for his daughter as a practice partner. Throughout the film, amir khan, who plays the father, is unsmiling and has the same serious expression that many fathers do. But these choices, and the hesitancy and determination of his choices, gave me a sense of the richness of this father.Geeta's success comes with a string of choices. After becoming a national champion, she opted for a more professional-looking coach, abandoning her father's skills. More importantly, she also gave up her focus on wrestling. In subsequent international competitions, Geeta did poorly. Meanwhile, the director deliberately accentuates the scene of Babita, the second daughter, and seems to want to abandon Geeta and turn Babita into a champion hero. In the difficult situation, Geeta chose to let go of her strong self-esteem and retrain according to her father's method. In the last moment of her father's absence, she chose to grow up alone, with a beautiful rainbow to win the gold medal, completed the transformation of an independent woman.Some film critics argue that a father pushing his daughter to train violates "women's rights". Yet women's rights have always been more than a slogan that can be easily uttered. The feminist movement in Europe and the United States began at the end of the 19th century. In the hard, dirty and dangerous textile workshops, working women have a choice to make: be content with what they earn, or fight for more women's rights. As reflected in suffragette, the hard-won right to vote for women was paid a heavy price by the feminist movement. Similarly, in post-world war ii America, when men returned from the war, women in military factories faced the dilemma of returning to their families or staying at work. After years of hesitation, American women have chosen to fight for women's rights. Women's rights meant accepting the "choice" test, not the easy life.Similarly, in India and many other developing countries, women's social status is low. Even if the most outstanding people to cry, it is difficult to change the traditional strong inertia. In the face of difficult choices, there is no way to have it both ways. It is true that the father forced his daughter at first. But as the father proudly declared, "let the daughter be strong enough to choose her husband". That's what makes movies valuable. It makes no secret of the cruelty of reality, whether it is early marriage, paternity, bureaucracy, or even the intensity and danger of wrestling itself. But for all the social problems, the film also holds a brave heart to choose. Father and daughter choose, act, then from humble beginning, until their own goal.Before the screen, we can also have a choice?

reviews.review_title: Really enjoyable, even for non-Bollywood fans
reviews.content: I'm not a Bollywood fan, so I went along expecting to have a nap. But wow! I really enjoyed this movie. It's well paced, very enjoyable and totally non-Bollywood.No music scores to slow the pace down; no love interest; no ridiculous fighting scenes; no shrieking female singing voice. Just a good story that keeps you guessing to the end. I enjoyed the humour, and surprisingly, it pulled on my heart strings. The music score was enjoyable and not a distraction. It was limited to incidental music that played during the montages.The 'fight scenes' were limited to wrestling matches, which were really amazingly choreographed. These were realistic and believable, and the hero didn't always win because she was the hero.Enjoyed this thoroughly, more than all the (Hollywood) movies I watched this year.

In portraying the image of oppressed women, this film took a different approach and selected two female wrestlers. For Gita and Babita, this is their only way out, but for more Indian women, their lives have been arranged early. It is also in such a social environment that the gold medal won by Gita at the end of the movie is so precious and so bloody. What impressed me most was that the father was locked in the dark room, I prayed silently not to let him out. I don't want to see actress regains the courage to defeat her opponent because of her father's arrival. Such an ending would make the film mediocre. Good thing is that the director didn't let me down. Her ability came from her father, but in the end she learned to fly alone.

Sports, the most important discipline of life, reboots your spirit mentally, physically, even professionally irrespective of you being a sportsperson or not. So also is DANGAL which primarily soars high on a balanced cocktail of women empowerment, discipline, emotion & moral values has captured the ardent relationship between father and daughter so candidly that you will find it impossible to control back your tears. Visionary veteran Mahavir Singh Phogat, against all odds of society, religiously manufacture his raw and uncooked daughters with utmost care prior to their introduction into the World of Wrestling which has been deliciously portrayed (literally yummy) by the ingenue Phogat siblings. While the energetic songs blend in seamlessly with a masterly written screenplay, the elder Phogat siblings raise the bar to the horizon performing through bout to bout. The choreography of bouts feel incredibly authentic on mat which is yet another genuine flavor in the biopic & as a vivid sports follower I must say that the dramatized scorelines will maintain the tempo upwards inside the theater. The entire cast & crew and the witty dialogues are again the contributing factor in this successful biopic besides the unnecessary pre-climax stunt and yes, Aamir- take a bow!!! It would be a sin if you don't watch DANGAL, it's movie of this era, it's gonna etch real hard on your thoughts and reverberate again and again. Go Play! Live your Life! 10/10

An American entertainer/comic actor, Late Andy Kaufman once said that " there is no drama like wrestling" and truly Aamir Khan and his team has cashed in this concept with 'Dangal'. There was not a single person without moist eyes as the curtains dropped in the theater. In one of the climax scene when the national anthem was played- many stood up (some with emotions and some due to peer pressure...) and applauded when one of the main protagonist wins the wrestling title. Dangal is based (partially) on a real life story of Mahavir Singh Phogat, who taught wrestling to his daughter, Geeta Phogat and Babita Kumari. Soundtrack of the movie is very earthy and so are the lyrics. Credits goes to the versatile Amitabh Bhattacharya who penned the beautiful songs and the music is composed by Pritam Chakraborty. The director (Nitesh Tiwari) and writer (Shreyas Jain) - without hammering the thought into the audience brain, beautifully pass on the message of gender equality and importance of hard work and patience.One of the main hero of the movie is the narrative style story telling and the acting of all the lead actors. This movie is worth a watch!! May this new year begins for all of us with the message that - There is no short cuts to success. You need to put in your blood and sweat in achieving your goals and have lot of patience to reach the summit in life.

reviews.review_title: Now this is the perfect example of how casting should be done. Not the best of the sports lot by all means, but certainly the way how these type of movies should be made.
reviews.content: Now this is the perfect example of how casting should be done. Amazing performances by all the 4 girls where Zaira Wasim (Young Geeta) has by far ruled the charts. Aamir's effort as an actor and producer are marvelous. Not the best of the sports lot by all means, but certainly the way how these type of movies should be made.Storyline Rating: 3Acting Rating: 4 Zaira Wasim: 4 Suhani Bhatnagar: 3 Aamir Khan: 4 Fatima Sana Shaikh: 3 Sanya Malhotra: 3Direction Rating: 3Music Rating: 4Cinematography: 3Editing: 4

reviews.review_title: Dangal: A masterpiece of a movie!
reviews.content: The year 2016 has been good for Hindi cinema. We have seen some very good films like Pink, Nil Battey Sannata, Sultan, Kapoor & Sons, Neerja, Airlift, MS Dhoni, Wazir and a few more.However, the year ends with Dangal, the finest & realistic Hindi sports film ever made and definitely the masterpiece of 2016.The film is based on national level wrestler and coach Mahavir Singh Phogat who taught wrestling to his two elder daughters Geeta & Babita at a time when women wrestling was looked down upon in India and Indians failed to get medals in international events. The film highlights their journey from childhood, their rigorous training, their sacrifices and the challenges and setbacks that they faced initially at the international level. However, both later went on to win gold and many other medals for India in several international championships in female wrestling.Talking about performances, every actor in the movie appears so realistic that one tends to forget that they are actors. Both the child actresses playing the two wrestlers are simply superb and their grown up versions are amazing as well. Aamir Khan playing their father with a huge paunch is as usual a riveting watch.The supporting cast is also terrific.Hats off to the director for making such a brilliant film. I can't find an obvious flaw in it. Well Done! :D

reviews.review_title: labeled Based on a True Story but simply Fictionalized
reviews.content: This movie proves that India is not yet ready for an honest biopic film. Although the film excelled in every other aspects such as acting, cinematography, special effects, music; especially MUSIC, But it couldn't capture the real aspect of the story of the wrestlers daughter and her sisters. We never get to know her enthusiasm towards wrestling. Was it her relationship with her father who imposed his dream of winning a gold on her? or her duty towards her nation to win it? or was it her own desire to never give up or lose to a competitive opposition to satisfy her own ego?This film was heavily clichéd just for the purpose of entertaining the masses and clearly may have aggravated many characters who are related to this story. TOO much HYPE may have given this movie the attention that it pursued, and why not? this is business after all.Much disappointed with the makers of the film for adulterating such an awesome script which may have had made everybody proud. Current IMDb score :9.2 with over 13k users. Where have we gone wrong?Final verdict: Its a good watch, but one wouldn't rate this movie 9/10 unless he/she had any personal attachment towards the film. it has good social message/dialogues. An 8 would be too generous, hence I would rate it 6 or 7 out of 10.

Whatever we had expected from a Aamir khan movie , he does it again. This time not only Aamir but the entire team of Dangal just Brilliant. Right from direction,screenplay,cinematography, background sound and of course the brilliant acting movie nailed it. I was stunned at the wrestling scenes projected in the movie. They are damn good real and nail biting. Absolute a treat to watch.. Loved each and every performance. I will recommend everyone to watch this masterpiece. I have no word to say.. The movie is still playing in my mind. Such a delight to watch.. Kudos to Aamir Khan for his weight transformation. I cannot rate this movie. 10, 20 30 stars.. Its the movie of decade.

An endearing tale of having and dream and the endeavor to achieve it. I must admit that after 'Madras Cafe', this is a movie which has rekindled my hopes that Bollywood can create technically sensible movies. The handling deserves an applause. The movie doesn't give much chance to the viewer to get distracted. One fact that I hate about any Indian work ranging from films to series is the incessant, loud and maddening background score and this is avoided in the movie. Nitesh Tiwari has done a fantastic job while seated in the writer's and the director's chair. The command of all the actors over the dialect is impressive.Emotions, philosophy and practical scenarios are blended well. Mahavir's realization that his daughters have inherited his talent reminded me of that scene in 'Kung Fu Panda' where the Master Shifu, otherwise disappointed, sees a spark in Po. 'Nothing succeeds like success' - the villagers first condemn, then make fun of the family and finally praise and celebrate Geeta's success. One can even see girls being sent to train with Mahavir. The movie does have some emotional spots - the girls getting accustomed to their father's orders about getting ready at 0500 hours, they realizing that their seemingly insensitive father is, in reality, struggling for their better future, Babita criticizing Geeta and reminding her that their success is solely due to their father's sacrifice and skills and that he is growing old, the mild friction between the sisters over performance and Geeta calling up her father, Mahavir summarizing Geeta's journey and begging the NIS committee for another chance for her, Geeta quoting "Bahut dinon ke baad papa ki gaaliyan khaayi, accha laga !", after more than a decade of a fortitudinous journey, Mahavir denied the chance to witness the most important match of his daughter's career Mahavir finally appreciating Geeta after the gold medal.What I always crave for is having technical/professional(whether it's a sport, an armed conflict, secret services and so on) aspects given the maximum footage in the movie. The training of the girls, the points system, the strategies used and the games shown are perfect pointers for a layman like me to make out the 'head or tail' of the wrestling. The movie shows how vocational skills and what is popularly known 'jugaad' in India are quintessential for survival. Daya's stitching, Mahavir's ideas ranging from building the wrestling ground in his own field, using cotton mats as a low-cost substitute for synthetic mats, using the video parlor to analyse Geeta's previous games are all simple but successful ideas to navigate through predicaments. Mahavir, instead of celebrating Geeta's silver medal, stays back to watch the games of the other semi-final pair to evaluate the opposition in the final.The movie deserves 10/10 for it's genuine humor sprinkled all over the movie - the girls pursuing her mother to get them relieved from the training, Mahavir's stone-cold attitude to the tantrums hurled by his daughters, Omkar's sufferings and the comments from the crowd generate giggles.The characters in the movie seem balanced and well-placed. Geeta and Babita - Both the kids and the adults have played their parts well, successfully delivering what is expected from the characters. Omkar - the mascot and the 'comic relief'. Right from his inception in wrestling till the end of the movie, . His narration across the movie . He's the one that has the lion's in the humor. His expressions when his jeans are shortened to make slacks for his sisters, the torture he faces while his sisters learn wrestling and his unfaltering support(jack of all trades) to Mahavir all make him a lovable character. Mahavir Singh - Amir Khan has impeccably played a father and a teacher. Letting his girls have 'Gol gappe' for the last time, putting them on a non-veg diet despite of his wife's protests, giving up his job and disregarding his health and enduring hardships just for the success of his daughters are all. Once again, after 'Ghazani', he has put the efforts to modify his physique to suit the demands of the screenplay.Success of a person comes from the selfless support of many people who act like background processes. From Daya to the local chicken shop owner, all touch the viewer's heart.I felt that the music and lyrics have been an odd couple in the movie. Honestly, I was not impressed by the music, Pritam isn't the best choice for such movies. Having said that, the title track is notable. Amitabh Bhattacharya has made a mark in penning apt lyrics, the one I liked most were of the song 'Haanikarak Bapu'.Similar to the two sides of a coin, the movie has several shortcomings that are both facts and the desire of the viewer to expect more from something that is good or better than earlier attempts. After the intermission, I could feel the emotional drama stepping in increasingly e.g: The discussion between Mahavir and Geeta on the night before the final match(reminds of 'Chak De' final match!). While it's normal in an Indian movie, this consumes valuable time in the length of the film which can be dedicated for more technical aspects of wrestling. The sudden leap of the film from Geeta's adolescence to becoming the national champion was a bit disappointing for me - a journey of being a school girl in a hamlet to being a national champion would have involved aplenty of professional challenges like facing injuries etc. The number of songs should have been less.The movie, undoubtedly, is one of the Bollywood's fine works and a must-watch(more than once!). I just hope that instead of having one such movie per decade, we have such movies frequently, focusing on diverse sports. I look forward to the movies that take a cue from 'Dangal' and improvise on the technical aspects.

reviews.review_title: 8.1/10 - I Was Pleasently Surprised By How Good It Was
reviews.content:
That was pretty interseting, I'd say. I had low expectations, since the plot summary didn't seem that interesting to me, but well...I was pleasently surprised.This Indian film (Dangal translates to "Wrestler") follows an Indian family. The father had to give up on his dream to win an international gold medal for India because of money issues when he was young, and once he got married he kept dreaming of having a boy, and making his dream come true through that boy. But every time that his wife got pregnant it turned out to be a girl. One day, the two girls pretty much thrashed two boys they got in a fight with, and so the father realized that he could make his dream come true through his girls. So yeah, that's pretty much what the movie is about. Btw, It's based on a true story.I find this film quite solid, actually. Yeah, it's not an artistic, sophisticated film with a lot of symbolism, breathtaking shots or brilliant dialogue. What makes this film stand out are two things, mainly:
1. The characters and the connections between them. Yeah, again, the characters are not brilliantly written or played or anything, but I think that they successfully creat an emotional connection to the father and daughters (Mahvir, Geeta and Babita), and the development the go through as they grow up is quite heartfelt. Yeah, this movie got me emotional from time to time.2. The cultural context. The soundtrack, the culture, the manners, the traditions...it was truly interesting to watch a film that dives that deep into the Indian culture, and also criticizes it in a way.Anyway, I don't have any major problem with this film. The soundtrack is good, the filming and cinematography are quite decent, and tho the ending is really predictable the film is very well made. Maybe it's because Disney were involved in the production. So, yeah. Just a well made film with relatable characters and a quite captivating plot.Feeling an 8.1/10 on this one.P.s
The wrestling scenes are legtimately thrilling. They were much more interesting than I expected.

This is a MUST WATCH film. Deeply entertaining, Dangal manages to do what few other Bollywood movies have ever accomplished: move and inspire the audience. A beautiful true story with themes of family legacy, gender dynamics and expectations, courage, and the state of Indian sports - all of which are seamlessly sewn together in a film that, though almost 3 hours long, keeps you glued to your seat from beginning to end. Aamir Khan is excellent, but Dangal's highest triumph lies in the power and grit of the young actresses portraying Geeta and Babita, as well as their older counterparts (especially Fatima Sana Shaikh, who steals the show with her raw beauty and strength). The wrestling scenes are realistic and flawless, containing some of the best editing I've ever seen in a sports film.

reviews.review_title: Dangal is a masterpiece biopic which is Emotional and Thrilling – and worth watching a 2nd time!
reviews.content: Dangal is a gem of a Biopic film – an unforgettable classic, in fact! It is a well-made film that will touch your heart and soul. It is a very emotional film (my eyes became wet in some scenes) which will make you fall in love with not just each and every character but also with the sport of female Wrestling. Dangal is not only emotional but also thrilling and highly inspirational as well! Dangal is now running to full houses throughout the day in all cinema halls. It is heart-touching film that is a MUST watch - not just once- but a few times, before you die.MERITS of Dangal1 – It is a based on a very good story (even if it is fictional it'd still be very, very good). 2 –Dangal is another directorial success by Nitesh Tiwari after his Chillar Party and Boothnath Returns. The Pacing and the Build-up of the story are just perfect!3 – The background music is OK in general but thrilling on certain occasions. 4 – You feel connected to and moved by each and every character – esp. that of Amir Khan and his brave and bindass daughters. If you watch this film, not just through your eyes, but also through your heart, I am sure your eyes will become moist during some scenes.5 – Amir Khan has given his heart, body and soul for the role of Mahavir Singh Phogat. You will be amazed to see his bodily transformation from a young muscular Mahavir to a pot-belied, grey-haired coach of his daughters, Geeta and Babita. His Haryanvi accent is absolutely perfect. No wonder Amir Khan is Mr. Perfectionist!6 – And how can I forget the WRESTLING scenes? Each of the WRESTLING bouts is well-choreographed and well-shot and well-edited too! It's riveting, thrilling and very tense. The close-ups just draws you INTO the action scenes. You will NOT forget the slo-mo scene of Geeta lifting the Nigerian wrestler from the front and throwing her backwards. It was a thrilling scene! That was the move which won her the Gold medal in the 55 kg in the 2010 Commonwealth Games in Delhi. It is indeed a refreshing cinematic experience for all of us, & esp. for the ladies, to see FEMALE WRESTLING on screen and the adrenaline rush it has created in those who've seen it on the big screen.7 – Zaira Wasim (younger Geeta) and Fatima Seikh (grown up Geeta) fought their wrestling bouts in a very realistic manner. In fact, they were actually trained in Wrestling for several months by a national-level wrestling coach, Kripa Shankar Bishnoi Beniwal. Hats off to these wonderful actresses for putting in so much hard work to learn the Wrestling moves, to make things look perfect!FYKI, Fatima was a child artist in Chachi 420 (1997). Remember?But I wonder why Babita (Sanya Choudhary) did not feature in any wrestling bout? Even then, FYKI, she trained with the other girls for months even though she had extremely short fight scenes. 8 – There are many amusing scenes and dialogues which looks very natural and fits well in the flow of the story, rather than looking out-of-place.9 – The songs in Dangal are very, very exhilarating. I just love the rustic flavour in each of those songs. I am pretty sure, from now onwards, all Indian wrestlers (current and future ones) will be listening to Dangal songs for motivation before the Wrestling match.10 – I loved hearing the Haryanvi accent in each of the character; although sometimes it may be difficult to understand. All the actors and actresses have got the accent right - and that is a must to create the right flavour in a story that is also based in Haryana. 11 – You will not feel even a single boring moment during the 2 hr & 40 minutes. Guaranteed!DEMERITS of DangalWhat demerits? It'd amount to nit-picking if I start finding demerits!Finally, 2016 was a great year for Hindi cinema. We are fortunate enough to witness some very thoughtful and well-made films that touched our hearts and souls. These films were biopics (Nirja, Dhoni, Dangal, Aligarh) and non-biopics (Pink, Parched, Dear Zindagi).

reviews.review_title: One of the best movies in World Cinema, hope like the story of the Phogats, Aamir brings India her first Oscar!!
reviews.content: Straight 10/10. Masterclass! There is something different in the type of movies that Aamir Khan acts in or directs. Before watching the movie and after, you come back and start reading more about the messages that is conveyed. That is so unlike any Shah Rukh or Salman Khan movie. the only other person that is worthy of this kind of action from the viewer's behalf is Farhan Akhtar. Dangal is a celebration of womanhood and is an inspiration to not just women but also a lesson to men to never think less of the capabilities of a woman! Aamir is just exceptional, the lengths to which he goes to be an actor and convey a message is just incredible. but that's why there is only one of Aamir Khan. That being said, I don't want to take away the class of the younger Geeta and Babita and the older Geeta and Babita. The kind of training that has been put in my them is incredible. Good acting is when you go the distance to be the character that you are representing and not act for the sake of a role! Hats off to Nitesh Tiwari for making such a movie that celebrates womanhood! Aparshakthi Khurana brings in the comedy.Hats off to the real life Mahavir Singh Phogat to have had the vision to empower his children, and think differently and uplift the spirits of women by doing what he did with his family. the reason why this is of importance is that in places like Haryana, women still get discriminated, even after India having had a woman Prime Minister and President! What I really loved too is 2 other things in the movie..1) the movie is not all serious. There is a lot of humor in a classic, non-offensive style which tells a story about victory in a humorous way. this has become extremely rare. 2) the songs show scenes of prep or training in the movie. this has become a great way to keep the audience fixed to their seat, so they don't just listen to the song and look around or look at their phones. I hope that this movie gets an Oscar! if Slumdog millionaire can, I don't see why Dangal cannot!

Nitesh Diwari's Dangal becomes a inspirational sports drama. Fatima Sana Shaikh impersonates Geeta Phogat in this biographical film. Amir Khan plays her father, and Sanya Malhotra portrays her sister. The real life story of Geeta Phogat has created headlines in the wrestling world. India has had a weak reputation in international wrestling, and female athletes, in particular, face oppressive social taboos. Three Indian states could show the movie tax free because it resonates rich tenets of fatherhood, sisterhood, family, and determination. Amir Khan Productions and Walt Disney Pictures would spend a budget of just ~1.2 million USD and gross ~11 million USD due to the popularity!

reviews.review_title: Differs from Reality but worth watching
reviews.content: The story is good and I think this is one of the few movies of Bollywood in which character development is so good. The music is good and the title song is amazing with lyrics. You can listen it to get some motivation.The cast of the movie did amazing job as every part they played is nice. You can laugh, you can cry at the same time as this movie is filled with such moments.

The "spoiler alert" is here only because I wouldn't know how to write without it. As this film is based on a true story, plot development (for this review, anyway) is probably less important than how the film was made.Think of the prototypical template for classical Indian films: background, despair, tragedy, redemption, and lonnngg -- with lots of music and some dancing to lighten the load. There you have it. Production values in Dangal are high, and acting from all sides is terrific, right down to the snarky behaviour of the Scottish wrestler near the end. All we missed in this rags-to-riches tour-de-force of athletic accomplishment were a small child dancing around a tree and then getting hit by a train.If I could have changed anything, it would have been to tighten the editing and reduce running time by about 30 minutes, though most Indian viewers would probably disagree. I also would have given Babita a bit more of her due, since the film opens with Geeta and Babita apparently equal in skill and circumstance. Those musical interludes for me (as a non-Indian) got in the way after awhile. The national coach was also made out to be something of a loose cannon.But here in Hong Kong, Dangal has generated an unusual amount of interest for a foreign film, and an Indian one to boot. The moral of the story--father knows best--will not be lost on local families.My last words: excellent film, probably an 8 or 9 if only it had a shorter, tighter running time.

reviews.review_title: Its the story of a wrestler who dreams to win Gold Medal for India at International level, Continuing with his obsession for getting Gold for India,
reviews.content: Directed by Nitesh Tiwari who has directed hit films like "Bhootnath Returns" and "Chillar Party" is now trying his direction skills with a biopic of Mahavir Singh Phogat who is a former wrestling champion from Haryana. The best part about this flick is the one and only Aamir Khan himself who is known as a perfectionist of Bollywood when it comes to giving best films to the box office. After two years of super blockbuster film "PK" 2014 where Aamir unleashed all the limits of his perfectionism, he is back with a bang again along with his 2016's super powerful flick "Dangal" which is a story about a former wrestler champion Mahavir Singh Phogat and his efforts for training his own daughters Geeta and Babita who are India's most well known and celebrated female wrestlers who have also garnered medals in Commonwealth Games. The flick is starring Aamir Khan, Sakshi Tanwar, Fatima Sana Shaikh and Sanya Malhotra. The film has already hit the theater's on December 23, 2016. And if you haven't planned to watch this film I have brought you 5 solid reasons to book tickets and watch "Dangal".1. Aamir's honest dedicationMr. Perfectionist (Aamir Khan) is a keen actor when it comes to exhibit the authenticity of his character in any of his film. In this film Dangal, Aamir has to exhibit one character in two different physiques according to the demand of script in which he plays both young and old Mahavir Singh's character which again has a twist. The young Mahavir Singh in an athletic, muscular and broad shouldered physique whereas the old Mahavir Singh who trains his own daughters for wrestling is a fat, chubby, over weight and pot bellied personality of 97 kg. To play such an overweight personality, Aamir ate whatever he wanted and put on weight to reach 97 kg almost 100 kg and then he prepared himself to lose weight to get back to a fit and muscular physique with six packs to play the young Mahavir wrestler's role. This is what we call honest dedication by an honest actor. Amir Khan fans always wait eagerly for his master flicks because this perfect actor always come up with an excellent and exceptional script to keep his fans and viewers engaged. "Dangal" the biopic of Mahavir Singh Phogat wrestler is not only about his athletic career but also about his inspirational journey as a father and a trainer of his own daughters who are India's well known female wrestlers.

reviews.review_title: Worth every second of everyone's time.
reviews.content: After watching this masterpiece, there will be just one word you want to say....Well you can't say anything, you will be speechless. There are movies which we enjoy and in time there comes a movie, which we live. This one's the later type. There isn't any scene which you can say boring or extra. There won't be any second where you will feel disconnected from the movie. DANGAL is the best movie of Aamir's career. Mr perfectionist should be applauded for this terrific piece of story telling. In short....stellar performances, brilliant background score, superb screenplay, heart touching story / script, this movie will inspire you many ways. Don't waste time....go and live it.

reviews.review_title: Dangal - A strong message to Indian Society
reviews.content:
A movi with very strong script and an emotional theme. This movie has certain background that highlights a concerning issue that Indian society is going through right now.
In India child sex ratio (0-6 years) is about 914 girls per 1,000 boys according to latest report and every year approximately 2000 girls are killed before or just after birth. This ratio is increasing with the passage of time. In India girls are often viewed as a burden because of structure of the society and complex dowry system.Prime Minister Modi has taken many inititatives recently like "Beti Bachao Beti Padhao". I don't know if this movie is the part of that compaign or not but it's story is very strong. Amir Khan performed very well. A must watch movie if you like social movies.
No hit song or romance; that's the only weak point this movie has.

reviews.review_title: Best Indian movie I've ever seen
reviews.content: I always believe that a good movie is nothing more than a solid story with some solid actors to act well, tell well, not about the so-called appearance level, special effects. The best example is this Indian inspirational film, which can make you excited and excited even if you don't watch sports. It can make the ordinary family become warm blood, vivid; It also allows you to see a lot of the problems that society has right now.

Really good movie, there is everything in it for everyone. Action, thriller, drama, music, lyrics. From young to old its for all. And above all its based on true story.The acting is spectacular, the movie maintains its pace all over, strong dialogues, blended music and intelligent lyrics. But above all its the action sequences in the movie. With the sound they just looks unbelievably real. For a moment I felt I was watching a real wrestle game rather than a movie.Bollywood has finally come out of its silly action, indifferent love story, big name actors, rain and dance.Its a must watch.

reviews.review_title: A movie worth the hype. Off the beat, still mainstream. Hard-smart work, and it shows.
reviews.content: These lines from the title track of this movie quite sum up Aamir Khan's work ethic and dedication. I am an ordinary cinema-lover, not a critic. I like to take the things for what they are and not for what they should have been. Now let me come to the point.Dangal is not just a movie, it's an experience. It does not end with its credits, it stays with you. It makes you laugh with its light humor, it makes you root for the leads presenting the juxtaposition of views in the beginning, its dialogues question your mind. It is said that 'Cinema is reflection of the society.' Well at-least that's what textbooks say. I need not explain the utter disregard in major mainstream cinema of India. But this movie, it creates a difference. It's mainstream because a 'super-star' (as we Indians like to call them) acts in pivotal role, but at its heart its an honest to God attempt to tell something which has been conveniently ignored by our mainstream cinema for quite some time, quite rebellious and off-the beat. The soundtrack uplifts the already brilliant scenes, the title track 'Dangal Dangal' and Dhaakad give you goose-bumps, whereas 'Naina' leaves you teary-eyed. Nowhere in the movie has a song been put for headlong reasons, every song carries the story forward. Efforts by its actors are 'effortless', whereas the most of the material I have read till now doesn't mention Aparshakti Khurrana, who plays nephew of Aamir Khan, in line with the entire cast, he also deserves a special mention. Boy, he made me laugh with perfectly timed delivery of jokes!Now, as I have stated, I am no film critic. So obviously, this movie may have its fair(?) share of flaws or its share of beyond comprehension brilliance. My write-up is completely based upon how I felt while watching the film and what stayed in my heart (and hope it stays for a long time) walking out that theater door. Take a bow, Aamir Khan, Nitesh Tiwari, The Girls, The Boys and Team 'Dangal.' What you've created here is here to be a 'misaal'.

reviews.review_title: Triumph of Indian Cinema - Aamir Khan & team deserves a Oscar for this one.
reviews.content: #Dangal - Certainly the triumph of Indian Cinema. A Film Not To Be Missed!! Caters to each & every section of the audience, even who are not movie lovers. Highly recommended!!Highest accolade for any story-teller is when the audience are not only curious for the next moment but starts living the story with the storyteller and are being emotionally delighted by the ups and downs of the story's protagonist. Amazed by the screenplay and direction of Nitesh Tiwari. Glad he presented such a strong subject in front of Indian audience with sheer brilliance. Even strong dialogues are presented in a very subtle way. No superficial melodrama. Every department excels.I don't know how to define the best Indian movie but 'Dangal' is certainly the Best Indian Sports Drama till date and for a very long time it will remain steady because of its story, performances and brilliantly shot sport (wrestling) scenes. In fact the quality of the sports scenes can compete with any Hollywood sports drama - highly gripping, emotional and very inspirational. Every 2nd or 3rd scene you just get goosebumps. I was genuinely spellbound. It deals with a very strong social issue of uplifting women in a society which is surrounded by strong patriarchal culture.As far as performances are concerned, the actors are being well cast on the grounds of their true potential. Zaira Wasim as young Geeta leaves strong screen impact (Born Superstar). Whereas, Fatima Sana Sheikh and Sanya Malhotra as Geeta & Babita (respectively) were super- awesome. All the four girls were just terrific in their concerned roles. Sakshi Tanwar justified her character beautifully. Special mentions: the actor who plays the coach Girish Kulkarni was great and Aparshakti who plays the cousin and narrator of 'Dangal' was endearing. And, finally the most passionate actor who has always changed the face of Indian Cinema,'Aamir Khan' - He has given a top- notch performance. In every scene, Aamir has just lived Mahavir. He truly deserves to be called as the finest actor. He seriously doesn't play Mahavir but he just becomes him. That pain and joy which he has shown on screen was so lively that you tend to salute Mahavir Singh for his sacrifices and struggle he has gone through.Although, there are minor flaws in the movie but surely can be ignored in front of the subject.But, I really don't have words to express the internal strength of #MahavirSinghPhogat & family #ExtremeRespect There's a line in the movie's title track - "Bande ki mehnat ko kismat ka saadar pranaam hai pyaare, Dangal Dangal" Hardwork always pays off!

Last movie which released for year 2016 ,but no doubt awe-inspiring and one of the best for year 2016 .Movie revolves around dream of Mahavir Singh Phogat (a National Champion) to win Gold Medal for his country ,his compulsion to give up wrestling and how he expected this dream to be fulfilled by his blood line (his son),only to end up locking up all this dream along with medals n certificates in an old trunk. One day his dream catches wing again when he finds out his elder daughter Geeta & Babita beat 2 boys black and blue. With this starts a journey of 2 girls from a small village getting trained by their enthusiast and maniac father against all the stigma associated with girls getting trained for wrestling to first Indian women wrestler to win an International medal. Movie is thoroughly captive with many witty dialogues and you can fully resonate with the passion and dedication of girls and father transforming their dream to reality. A MUST WATCH !!! Merry Christmas and Happy New year

Dangal Review:- I believe that movies with longer shelf life's are getting lesser day by day..there are very few movies which qualifies into that category that urges you to stop and watch them whenever you found them while changing any movie channelsI am pleased to announce one more entrant into category which is the latest AK blockbuster  Dangal. AK has been 5th time lucky with his December release Last time when you have seen AK at the village backdrop you were cheering him for the nail biting cricket match and I am sure this time you would do that for his daughter thrilling wrestling techniques, as he moved into much mature real time character Mahavir Singh Phogat. Not in a single frame you found him glamorous but still he manages to steal the show just by his sheer flawless performance n into the character approach. Mind you this movie is far beyond any comparison with Sallu Bhai Sultan, except for Harynavi & Bajaj Scooter. This one apart from giving you many insight about wrestling as a game (points 1, 3 &5 was explained very well) also deals very beautifully about the father-daughter relationship along with social hurdles for a women wrestlers. All in you could found a different AK with various shades of father, coach, mentor, wrestler etc. and the dialogue delivery from him that too in Haryanvi style was just a killerwith various inspirational and true to life messages. The movie is lengthy but with amazing screenplay, balanced 1st and 2nd halves, great supporting cast it makes the overall experience joyful n memorable right from beginning till end. Moreover even though the songs are not chart busters but it was superbly placed and it gels properly with the flow of the story and you would never found people moving out of the halls for some refreshments even when the songs are being screened. Daler Mehndi voiced title track which keeps coming in between pumps you with excitement n energy. Very well written and well sung. The second half was a clash between father ideology and daughter's approach which was so well portrayed and the father vs daughter wrestling and the climax was just mind-blowing. The new director had done full justice to the script and characters, from the opening scene of the movie one could very well judge his caliber and could hope that he keeps up the good work in his next venture otherwise he would be also gone missing like director of Sarforash. The pre- climax discussion between AK and his daughter will reminds you of Chak De 70 mint. But this time it was more emotional and realistic in Haryanvi style. Dangal's Mahavir Singh gives you many take awaythat a person with strong conviction could change anythingjust look at his confidence and belief during talking with butcher at meat shopI can only be a father or a coach at one point of time"Dangal ladnay se pehalay daar se ladana pedtha hai"etc there are many more and shouldn't be missed. All the sport biopic Chak DeBhaag Milkha BhaagMS Dhoni and this one too sends out a very strong message that "Success is sweet but its secret is sweat"!! Do watch this Dhakad movie and I promise that you will come out from the hall with happiness all around.

DANGALIt is easy to classify Dangal as just another feel good movie – but it goes way beyond that. Much has been written about the story line which does not bear repetition; the unfulfilled dreams of a champion wrestler who feels cheated of an opportunity to seek an international Gold and glory for the country due to circumstances, who seeks to fulfill them through his offspring.Where the Dangal experience becomes different is in the nuances and narration of the story. The reaction of a dejected Mahavir Singh Phogat (played by Aamir Khan) to the complaint by the villagers after his daughters beat up a couple of boys is one of surprise and elation – the real 'aha' moment for him when he realizes a Gold medal is a Gold medal, whether won by a girl or a boy. The natural resentment of the young girls to the harsh discipline imposed by the ambitious father is played out charmingly through the pranks and scheming of the siblings. The odds which are stacked against girls getting into a typically 'macho' sport like wrestling, starting with a conventional mother who refuses protein rich non vegetarian cooking at home to snide comments from the audience who wait to see how the girls will dress to wrestle against boys are emphasized without using high drama or decibels but with telling effect. The underplaying of the politics and harassment of women sports persons and stressing only on the inflated egos of the national coaches at the National Sports Academy keeps the focus strongly on the sport and ensures that the audiences are not distracted from the main story.The performances of the female cast is outstanding; Sakshi Tanvar who is better known for her role in the TV serial Kahani Ghar Ghar Ki plays Mahavir's quietly supportive but strong wife adequately. The Phogat sisters played by Fatima Shaikh and Sanya Malhotra bring the right balance of emotion and natural exuberance of youth. A very special mention needs to made of the young lad who plays their young cousin Omkar (whose grown up role is played by Aparashakti Khurana) who is brought in by Mahavir as the first sparring partner for the girls when they are initiated to the sport; he is in complete awe of his Chacha Mahavir but as a rather unlikely wrestler takes a lot of spills and beating in the process of helping the girls realize their métier.Aamir always brings something special to his home productions. As the emotional, temperamental and obsessive father and coach he walks the thin line between being a tough coach and a doting father. Without going over the top, he maintains his authority over his children with no screaming or third degree methods; however, there is never any doubt about who the boss is! Another masterpiece from him.The real test of a biopic is the ability to sustain audience interest when you know what follows next. Director Nitesh Tiwari has kept up just the right momentum through the movie to ensure that we look forward to every stage of the movie in spite of knowing what to expect. Perhaps the contrived climax scene and the prolonged early training scenes could have been constructed better; but then this is really nit picking on an otherwise exhilarating movie. After starting the movie with the National Anthem thanks to our Supreme Court, finishing it too on screen with the anthem at the medal ceremony was a master stroke which make sure that you leave the theater on a high!

reviews.review_title: In India we celebrate the struggle and not the medals
reviews.content: This movie again shows why we shower heaps of praise and crores of rupees on couple of silver and bronze every 4 year. The adulation is not about 2 medals in a country of 1.2 billion heads but it's the hard fought struggle and an impossible journey of those 2 people that change the way we think and look sport as a field in this country. Amir Khan as have been the trend from past few years, brings you the as real as Mahavir can be in the biopic, but the highlight are the scenes like- villagers frowning upon girls taking wrestling, Geeta and Babita realizing the true intention of their father at Mehendi, denying Geeta from competing in dangal at first and then allowing only for the cheap publicity and so; all these lay out the struggle the girls especially from rural areas face. Amir was outstanding as usual, Geeta and Babita's performance as kids outrank the young one and surprisingly given the small screen presence, Geeta and Babita's cousin was entertaining. First half was too good and is enthralling, however after intermission you could feel like there were one or two odd pieces where the direction was not that good and 'bollywood' dramatization also ruled few scenes. Overall movie is great and with the voices of Daler Mehendi in title track make it inspiring and a must watch.

reviews.review_title: A perfectly mediocre film only worth watching for the terrific fight sequences
reviews.content: Not only does Dangal methodically check off every sports movie cliché out there, it goes a step further into general movie clichés. Initially, I almost forgave some of them because it is, after all, "based on a true story", but as it turns out, it changed a lot of facts to fit those clichés. Artistic liberty makes sense when used to increase dramatic tension, but to make the story worse? That's just missed potential.The actors do a good job, especially Fatima Sana Shaikh, who plays the wrestler Geeta Phogat with just the right mix of intensity and vulnerability. Babita Kumari, played by Sanya Malhotra, is unfortunately sidelined to a mind boggling degree, the film being only concerned with what she meant to Geeta, and never interested in her as a subject.Thematically, it gets tricky. From a sports drama perspective, it is definitely inspiring to see the sacrifices that are required for Geeta and Babita to get where they need to be, but the film also tries to push itself as feminist, which doesn't work because the sacrifices the women make are forced on them by their father, Mahavir Phogat, who seems far more concerned with seeing his children fulfill the dreams he once held for himself than he is with helping them achieve what they want for themselves. When the girls complain about this, there is actually a scene, and I'm not kidding, where another girl tells them "at least your father isn't forcing you to get married to someone you've never met." Because forcing them to give up any hope for a happy childhood in service of a dream they do not dream is so much better *sarcasm*. A big part of the reason this doesn't work is the presentation, as instead of leaving the question of whether Mahavir's position was justified up to the viewer to answer, the film glorifies him as an ideal to follow, and every time there's an opportunity to show us that the sisters are, in fact, enthusiastic for the sport, the moment is instead used to depict enthusiasm for winning, enthusiasm for respect, enthusiasm for pleasing their father, and even, out of nowhere, enthusiasm for making the country proud.Apart from being thematically muddled, the movie is plagued with narrative problems such as unnecessary voice-overs explaining how a character is feeling, abrupt transitions to pointless songs, simplistic, one-dimensional villains (why did this film need villains anyway? Wasn't society enough?) and montages that last forever, leading to a bloated 160-minute runtime.And yet I think it's overall an okay movie because outside of the fights, the humor is enough to tide you over, and when the fight scenes are on, in spite of the predictable outcomes, it's a blast.Overall, I wouldn't recommend seeing Dangal. It's not like it's in dire need of your money anyway.

reviews.review_title: Bizarre excuse for a troubled parent
reviews.content: Aamir Khan is known for being involved in films with a clear social message. After the insightful Taare Zameen Par (2007) and 3 Idiots (2009) declared that society is ruining children by pitting them against each other in mindless competition, Dangal (2016) does a 180 degree flip and celebrates ruining children by pitting them against each other in mindless competition. The father deals with his own personal insecurities by living vicariously through his daughters, denying them any of their own development or agency and reducing them to actors in his own personal fantasy that is under his control. In doing so, he shreds whatever is left of their education, social standing and health and dismisses these side effects as not "real" problems. His ambitions go far beyond instilling a normal type of achievement and goal-setting in his children. In any sane world, his parenting style would be recognised as toxic and he would be the villain of his story. Yet he's supposedly doing them a favour because the only other life alternative for women was forced marriage and domestic work. You heard it right, he liberated his daughters from having their fate imposed on them... by having their fate imposed on them. The only reason I rated this film so highly is that it's actually very well made, with relatable actors, exciting action scenes and a clear sense of progressing energy.

#DANGAL review (No spoilers) The best thing about DANGAL is that there is no Aamir Khan- the superstar in the entire movie. There is just Mahavir Singh Phogat and his family. Their day to day struggles and their small triumphs ultimately leading to gold. It's a story of wrestling, of family, of emotions and basically everything which a person pursuing sports other than cricket experiences in India. It is also a deeply inspiring story of feminism. Geeta does what Aarfa Khan in Sultan couldn't. Aamir does what Salman couldn't- bring a character to life without the use of VFX. His character has many layers throughout the film. Was it his best performance till date? Well, we say that every alternate December. But like Virat Kohli, Aamir keeps scaling new heights in his every new innings.. A special mention of Daler Mehendi whose energetic rendition of title song which keeps giving you an adrenaline rush. Watch it for pure cinematic brilliance. For the amazing dedication of actors Zaira Wasim and Fatima Sana Shaikh who play the younger and grown up Geeta in the movie respectively. Their wrestling scenes are unimaginably real and goosebumps inducing. And yea, if you can also stand up for the national anthem.

This movie is Nitesh's best movie. Dangal became the finest movie of year 2016 in Bollywood.The execution and direction of the movie is superb. It shows the mindset of the people in villages (and most of the part of India) who thinks that daughter is just Load to their family and have only place for house Hold work. Mahavir Singh Phogat (Aamir's character) fight all the odds and train his daughters to be professional wrestlers. The movie also brings the mindset of the India Parents, that they can chose the future of their children and prepare them for it.Movie don't take much time to collect and start the story. The in-depth story of the daughters training session is very interesting and you will get attached to it. Action sequences of Geetha's matches are very well executed in early age and later the professional matches. The only disappointed part in the movie is to bring the NSA coach as bad character who conspire to put Mahavir in a room while Geetha play final match. Movie picks a Melodrama (wasn't necessary) at that stage.Overall performance: 8/10

reviews.review_title: This is what you call a MASTERPIECE!!!
reviews.content: Dangal, without any doubt, can be considered as one of the greatest films of Bollywood. It is a kind of movie that shakes you from inside and touches your every emotional cord. The movie splendidly portrays the struggle of a father for his daughters by going against all odds and thus making the country proud. Director Nitesh Tiwari has magnificently brought the real essence of the film by keeping the authenticity and beauty of the incredible story intact. The direction and screenplay are so good that the representation makes you laugh and cry at the same time, filling your heart with euphoria and proud. 10/10 for this. But no perfect story can be succeeded without having a proper engine attach to it, and the most powerful engine of this story is Aamir Khan, who I think, has delivered his career best performance. He makes you laugh, astonishes you and fills your eyes with tears. You can easily see a struggling father in him, who is willing to face any hardships and can go to any limit to make his daughters "best of all", and fulfill his dream to make the nation proud. Again 10/10.. Not only Aamir Khan, other stars of the film like Zaira Wasim (young Geeta), Suhani Bhatnagar (young Babita), Sanya Malhotra, Fatima Sana Shaikh, and all other supporting cast have done extremely well and deserve huge applause. Music of the film mixes well with the taste and genre of the movie. The timings of the songs are impeccably perfect. So in short, Dangal is once in a lifetime movie that not only entertains you with its great story and performances but also makes you think about the strong message ("Mhaari choriyaan choron se kam hai ke?"), it is trying to convey you. A great film that gives you a great social message by spellbinding you with its great story and presentation. A MUST WATCH!!!

An inspiring movie that shows the rise of female-power and dreams from the society in which girls are considered as backward. This movie is on the life and struggles of ex-wrestler cum coach Mahavir Singh Phogat and his two daughters Geeta & Babita to follow in his footsteps and become world-class wrestlers. Aamir was outstanding in his role as Mahavir Singh Phogat. The girls (both in young ages and when grown up) were good in their performances. The storytelling was quite appreciable as well as its cinematography. Another credit goes to Nitesh Tiwari, the director. This movie seems to be the greatest gift of the year by Bollywood. Aamir Khan will be reminded for his performance like he is in his other movies.Finally Mr.Perfectionist with his girls has proved their "Dhaakad".

reviews.review_title: We see the blood, sweat and tears that go into the making of champions.
reviews.content: Dangal is an outright winner - A film that will pin you down and keep you in its grip all the way through. Dangal works on the twin parameters it sets up for itself. One is a straight-forward film about a popular sport and those who play it: we feel and smell the 'mitti' of the 'akhara', the 'daanv-pench' (moves) that truly skilled wrestlers use to face down formidable foes. We see the blood, sweat and tears that go into the making of champions. The actors who play the young Geeta and Babita do a competent job of turning into eager combatants from young-girls-who-just-want-to-have- fun. Dangal sees Aamir Khan as wrestler Mahavir Singh Phogat, who trained his daughters Geeta and Babita Phogat who went on to win medals for India in wrestling.

reviews.review_title: Entertains and Inspires, An Epic Movie for all Ages
reviews.content: Wow - if I could sum up Dangal in one word, and that wow goes especially to the choreography of the wrestling matches between the character Geetha and her opponents and also on the visual capture of these matches. In terms of sports action in Bollywood, I loved Chakde India but Dangal simply outshined it in that aspect. Maybe I can say that the sports action in Dangal is as good as those from Hollywood, at least in terms of sheer suspense and thrill factor. Dangal is even like a beginner's lesson on what wrestling is for viewers :D and that's because there are scenes in the movie that explains(via Aamir's character to his kids) in an uncomplicated, interesting manner on how the points work or explains the various attack or defense moves. Besides the excellent sports choreography(the Commonwealth Games semifinals match is my favorite) and the cinematography, the performances and also the direction deserve a big applause. Aamir gives an aptly controlled performance as the centrestage actually belongs to the character of Geetha. If he'd not taken a backseat whenever required to let the other actors shine in some key scenes, this movie would have stumbled. Fatima Sana Sheikh as the older Geetha gets the role of a lifetime. She must have trained very hard to do justice to such a physically demanding role and her emotions are spot on too but if I were to choose just one performance in the movie that's my favorite, I would say Zaira Wasim as the younger Geetha. What a natural child actor! And of course, the support cast is wonderful like Sanya Malhotra as the older Babita(sis of Geetha), Suhani Bhatnagar as the young Babita and Ritwik Sahore(young Omkar, the Phogat sisters' cousin). The child actors, I must mention again, Zaira Wasim, Ritwik Sahore and Suhani Bhatnagar deserve lots of appreciation for their acting. Of course, as it is a movie, the makers take liberties to exaggerate a few moments or scenes or even bring shades of grey to few characters which is all OK but at what point does one limit it? Geetha's national coach in the movie is shown to have shades of grey, exaggerated grey actually, so much so that PR Sondhi(who was the national coach of Geetha & Babita in real life) remarked that his reputation has been hurt by what's shown in the movie and they should have not taken such liberties with the character at his expense. I agree. Otherwise I'd have rated this movie a 9 or even a 10(it's still epic) but I downgrade it to 8 as a symbolic protest to how some of the characterisation was done.Verdict: It is "bollywood-ish" but still entertains, thrills and inspires in equal measure. Bring your family to the theatre too, and also it runs with English subtitle for a wider audience. As soon as the DVD is out, I intend to buy and watch it again. A must see despite any flaws.

ITS DANGAL DANGAL.............Yet another Christmas and the perfectionist is back with a bang. It is inspiring, it is emotional, it is thrilling and they named it "DANGAL".If you are going to avoid this movie by comparing it with Sultan with a prejudice mind, I must say you are terribly mistaken. Sultan was a mere entertainment while Dangal is a class apart. Amir khan once again proved why he is called as the perfectionist of Btown. His efforts for this move has to be appreciated. We all know what this man is capable of and must say that he deserves the credit for portraying such a role which eventually concentrates on the female characters as the movie progresses. That shows how passionate he is about this art called cinema. His transformation from the macho man to old age fatty human was absolutely magical but the same time his eyes had the same intensity all the way long.Coming to the caste, Zaira Wasim and Suhani Bhatnagar as the young Geeta and Babitha were absolutely flawless and charming. For me they were the Pick of the caste considering their age and experience, while Fatima and Sanya were there pretty closely with their outstanding performance. Supporting casts comprises of Sakshi Tanwar, Rohit, Gurish Kulkarni and others did a pretty decent job that even their comparatively small roles made the movie much more engaging.Music by Pritam Chakraborthy have already made big buss in the market and I believe that this definitely there as his one of the bests. DOP and Editing were top notch and editing deserves a special mention for making the movie thrilling. It is pretty evident that they have done great homework on the script and even a single minute of the was not boring.The movie tightly slaps on the conventional thinking of society that the women are only intended to live to look after their family and should stay back behind the curtain for specific reasons and the Man Mahavir Singh Rana was their to thrash all those concepts and in the end we could feel the satisfaction he might have had in the real life. Like I said before the movie had many thrilling moments to make you bite your nails. It made my eyes wet at times, It even made me proud when the national anthem sounded in, knowing the facts that its just a movie. The movie starts of with, showing the passion Mahavir Singh has for wrestling from their the half an hour it was Amir show and slowly he handed over the baton to the ladies to perform. I do not want to spoil the experience by detailing the script and moments which made me enthralled. The good thing was the makers did not use their cinematic freedom to exaggerate the things and whatever we saw on the big screen were quite convincing within their limitation of detailing a real life eventNow to the real life Mahavir Singh and Daughters, You people are the true champions, Hats off to your efforts and you people will always be remembered in our hearts. I hope your stories will inspire many others to follow and apparently it will bring many Olympic medals and fame to our country in the coming years.....I just do not want to rate this movie, Rather a movie I love to call it as an experience. It is indeed a MUST WATCH

reviews.review_title: Yet another classic from Mr Perfectionist's stable
reviews.content: Along with some of the greatest sports movies ever made in Bollywood, Dangal will probably be amongst the top 3 or top 5. Chak De India, Jo Jeeta Wohi Sikandar (yet another Aamir Khan movie), Bhaag Milkha Bhaag maybe few more that comes to mind. One of the brilliant facts about the movie gotta be its casting. Almost entire starcast is unheard of. Yet everyone have given such an amazing performance! Again, it maybe easier to find another actor who can dance and sing around. But not easy to find someone who can wrestle like an International athlete. I maybe biased for Aamir's best work being Taare Zameen Par, but this certainly comes close. The transformation of a National level wrestler to an aging old father, past his prime, the Haryanvi accent, the gait, everything about Mr Khan is just perfect. Besides, when was the last time you could take your entire family to a movie you were cringing at certain scenes, maybe some scenes were too violent, or raunchy - this is a movie you could and should take all your children (esp girl children) to watch. It also tends to be patriotic without being preachy. Last word: I wish they make this film tax-free. Everyone, esp all children and parents should watch this.

An excellent movie. Outstanding performance by Aamir Khan. Best Movie of the year. The girls (both kids and the grown ups) established their role very well. Special mention should be given to Nitesh Tiwari - the director. Music by Pritam is good. The cinematography is nice. The story telling is excellent. Overall a very inspiring movie. Watch this movie for Aamir Khan. Hands down to Aamir. His role as a wrestler/coach Mahavir Singh Phogat will be marked as one of his best. This film will come as one of the best sports films based on the life of coach after Chak De and Iqbal. I strongly recommend this film. In India other actors should think like how Aamir Khan thinks. He is a brilliant actor and his unique thoughts makes him special and perfectionist. I give Dangal 10/10. Really "Dhaakad Hai".

Yet another perfect movie from the perfectionist. Dangal gives you a peek in to people's lives who have a commitment towards sport and passionate towards nation but also the problems they face while they fulfill their dreams. Entire cast Aamir, Sakshi, Fatima, Saanya, Zaira and Suhani did an excellent job and justice to their roles. Needless to say Aamir excels to do what he is good at and keeps you occupied with his intense acting. The female leads (especially the younger and older Geeta) were awesome in their roles when it comes to the tackle scenes be it in the mud or on the turf. reviews.review_title: Gold medals will not come in an overnight of hard work
reviews.content: First of all, we should say hats off to Mahavir Singh Phogat, he is an Indian amateur wrestler and senior Olympics coach. He is the father of Geeta Phogat and Babita Kumari who had won the gold medal in commonwealth games [1,3,4]. This movie is all about their life's story including their character's names. This movie says that medals do not need particularly gender either male or female at all to play any game, it's all depends on the way we perceive.Hero (Amir Khan): There are very fewer personalities in Indian cinema industry who will dedicate more towards the story. Here, Amir khan molded two personalities by decreasing weight as much as 22-25 kilograms and vice versa for increasing to get the real feel of characters, in spite of having a risk to do the same.Generally, father and Guru will not be able to show their feelings on a single platform. Here, Amir Khan managed both in a perfect action. Hats off to Amir Khan.Direction and Screenplay: Nitesh Tiwari narrated and directed the movie in a good manner. However, the screenplay is a little bit slow to connect it.Traditionally we are unable to get more medals in the international forum, because of less motivation from the government and self-motivation as well as from the parents to support completely from childhood on words.Message from the film:For any game to play, it should be always habituated from childhood onwards and also make sure as an individual part that it should not have deviation at any point of time/or circumstances.The bottom line of the film: Rome wasn't built in a day [4]; in the same manner, we should never get anything in an overnight of hard work. References:1. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mahavir_Singh_Phogat2.https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Babita_Kumari3.https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geeta_Phogat4.https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rome_wasn't_built_in_a_day

It is one of the best movies in the history of India; the plot is very good, the performances are excellent and the music is quite good. TOTALLY RECOMMENDED!

reviews.review_title: One of the rare feel good films in today's time
reviews.content: It is indeed very rare to find films of this nature in today's Bollywood cinema. A feel good film that is inspirational from which an individual and even the country can look upon. A film needs to have a strong story line to create an impact and DANGAL provided just that. The audience demands good story/script these days and are willing to watch a movie with strong script even if the actors are not well known. Sadly, there does exist some blind fans who blatantly makes other actors such as Salman Khan movies hit even if those don't have good story in it. DANGAL has strong story, great star cast and good performance. A must watch.

The Phogat Sisters, against all odds, created history for Indian Sports in the year 2010. Though we read about them in the headlines, we hurriedly moved on to other 'more interesting' news. They went on, fighting their battles alone, to bring more than thirty international medals for our country. We saw their names in the news, raised our eyebrows, and refocused back on our game of cricket. They again came, this time with their father, and gave an inspiring small interview on the TV show Satyamev Jayate. This time we sat up a bit, and 'spent' on them, a little 'encouragement clap'.It finally took a two hours forty nine minutes of full fledged Bollywood feature film to make us at last, give them the applause they have been deserving since long. At last, the magic of cinema and storytelling works and the same we, now open new tabs and start to google about Geeta, Babita and their hero, Mahavir Singh Phogat.Written by four Ad-professionals including the director Nitish Tiwari, Dangal, hooks you from the very first go. The humorous narrative of the 'sacrificial goat-ish' brother becomes almost addictive till the last scene.Here's the story of a middle-aged man with unfulfilled dreams who has given in to his defeated life as his ill fate. Until one day when he realizes that all this while the road to all his dreams had lain just in front of him, but it was only his own superfluous beliefs, which had closed his eyes. He quickly corrects himself and now aims for the Sun and no less. So what if it is his sparky girls not 'society-accepted' boys who will achieve this feat for him. So the endearing struggle starts of two unwilling girlish girls ( a brilliant young Geeta played by Zaira Wasim) who are turned into tomboys by their 'haanikaarak' father. It is only at a friend's wedding, that they realise their good luck of having such a man as their father who considers them human enough to love and care about their future. A single dialogue of the little bride voices all those vices to which so many Indian households are still entangled. This struggling phase is very thoughtfully shot in a muddy shade of color by Cinematographer Sethu Sriram.Adult Geeta and Babita Phogat are flawlessly played by Fatima Sana Shaikh and Sanya Malhotra. But Sanya surprisingly has got much lesser vocal and fighting scenes in comparison to Fatima. Although she is kind of sidelined, it is she who shines brighter with her sincere portrayal of silent understandings of the war of emotions happening between her sister and father. Unfortunately Sanya's Babita is at the end reduced to being just a cheer girl to her sister who solely claims the limelight in the later half of the film. One wonders why, considering Babita Phogat's equal if not more, achievements in her own matches. Amir Khan is so good as Mahavir Singh Phogat that after a point of time, he makes you forget that he is Amir Khan himself. You only see the character. That calls for an applause. Sakshi Tanwar as the wife, Daya Kaur,the silent support system of her family is wonderful. Her large expressive eyes speak volumes more than spoken words.Dangal is about wrestling. Wrestling on the on mats. Wrestling inside minds. The wrestle between a visionary father and the 'blind' society he lives in. A blind society 'we' still live in.Celebrating woman power, bringing hope and rekindling patriotism, is Dangal, a perfect end to a Bollywood year full of strong female protagonists.Hopefully now, the Haryana Government will consider keeping the promise they made to the Phogat Sisters four years ago and finally pay them the much needed, awaited and deserved, 50 lakhs rupees award.

It is one of the rarest & finest Hindi movie in its genre, a much needed biopic on sports drama in the era of trash movies and junkie talkies. Every single actor or individual associated with the movie seems to have dedicated themselves completely produce such effective cinema. And what can i say about the maestro himself? Watch him in a scene when he engages in an argument/fight with Geeta or that phone conversation or the way he trains and coaches his daughters as it feels like you are watching the real Mahavir Singh himself who has so much passion for wrestling....absolutely brilliant!
